abstracts.cdata!:
The Azerbaijan Urgent Environmental
            Investment Project had a satisfactory outcome, likely
            sustainability, modest institutional development impact, and
            satisfactory Bank and Borrower performances. Lessons from
            the project are: 1) Having a diligent and flexible approach
            to implementation helps address design shortcomings and
            reorients the project to achieve development objectives. 2)
            Put in place institutional structures to sustain project
            activities early during project implementation, and phase in
            their independence instead of suddenly cutting them off from
            financial and technical support when the project closes. 3)
            Clearly identify desired outcomes in pilot activities and
            include follow-up. 4)When remediating contaminated land,
            identify and address institutional aspects such as land
            ownership and land use planning up-front to avoid illegal
            land occupation. 5) Clarity regarding fiduciary
            responsibilities, is important when an agency other than the
            parent Ministry is responsible for implementing one
            component. 6) Be realistic regarding how quickly it is
            possible to transform activities and institutions that were
            historically state-operated to a model based on a
            commercial, market-based approach. 7) Capacity building
            needs to address development of professional management
            capability, not just technical aspects. 8) For technical
            assistance to be effective, the government and implementing
            agencies have to regard it as useful for achieving highly
            desired outcomes. In this project, technical assistance
            effectively supported implementation and built local
            capacity through on-the-job training.

repnme.cdata!:
Azerbaijan - Urgent Environmental
            Investment Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urgent Environmental Investment
            Project involves building a sturgeon hatchery, oil field
            cleanup, and mercury cleanup. In regard to the sturgeon
            hatchery, water pollution during the hatchery operation will
            be minimized by proper wastewater treatment. Hatchery wastes
            will be collected in concrete bins and burned regularly. To
            mitigate the impact of cross-breeding of sturgeon species,
            tanks will be used to segregate various species of breeding
            stock and roe will be hand fertilized from know donor
            species. There will be measures to control dust from the
            feedmill and worker training to minimize exposure. To clean
            up the oil field, wastes will be categorized by contaminants
            and severity for disposal. There will be adequate on-site
            storage facilities for handling recovered oil. Anti-dusting
            measures will be used during the oil field cleanup. The
            major impact of the mercury cleanup is the removal and safe
            disposal of a large amount of toxic mercury. A mercury
            recovery technology which meets international standards will
            be used. After the mercury recovery, the soil will be
            dewatered and then transported to the landfill for safe
            disposal by covered trucks along a route away from inhabited
            areas. Pilot tests will be carried out to identify an
            effective way of dewatering and stabilizing waste sludges
            stored on the mercury recovery plant site. Excess water will
            also be treated before discharge to the Caspian Sea.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urgent Environmental Investment
            Project aims to direct action in four areas identified in
            the Azeri National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP), which
            are critically important for Azerbaijan's environment
            and economy, relatively small, and considered urgent. This
            project has 5 components. Component 1 restores the capacity
            of Azerbaijan to produce sturgeon fingerlings by building a
            new hatchery; and creates a sustainable institutional and
            financial basis for future hatchery operations. Component 2
            demonstrates mercury cleanup technologies and procedures by
            decontaminating one heavily polluted area. It tests
            pilot-scale sludge treatment; develops and applies a
            low-technology method for mercury recovery; transports
            wastes; constructs a safe, new landfill; designs and
            implements a monitoring program for mercury emissions; and
            does a follow-up assessment. Component 3 tests cleanup
            methodologies on a pilot basis and mitigates existing
            pollution in one onshore oil field of the Abseron peninsula.
            It finances a series of pilot projects to determine the most
            cost-effective method for treating oil-contaminated
            sediments and sludge; cleans up oil residues; and continues
            operating the implementation unit in the state's oil
            company. Component 4 strengthens the environmental
            management system by reviewing its legislative and
            regulatory framework and building the capacity of the State
            Committee of Ecology. Component 5 consists of project management.
